National Sentence Text: Where a cleanout is required on a building sewer 8 inches or larger in size, it shall be a manhole.
P/T Sentence Text: Where a cleanout is required on a building sewer 8 in. or larger in size, it shall be a manhole.

National Sentence Text: A building sewer shall not change direction or slope between the building and public sewer or between cleanouts, except that pipes not more than 6 inches in size may change direction by not more than 5° every 3 m, or by the use of fittings with a cumulative change in direction of not more than 45°.

Building drains shall be provided with a cleanout fitting conforming to Sentence 2.4.7.2. that is located as close as practical to the place where the building drain leaves the building. (See Note A-2.4.7.1.(6).)
P/T Sentence Text: Every sanitary building drain or storm building drain shall be provided with a cleanout fitting that is located as close as practical to the place where the drain leaves the building.

National Sentence Text: Soil-or-waste stacks shall be provided with a cleanout fitting at the bottom of the stack, not more than 3 m upstream of the bottom of the stack, or on a Y fitting connecting the stack to the building drain or branch.
P/T Sentence Text: Every soil or waste stack shall be provided with a cleanout fitting,  at the bottom of the stack,  not more than 1 000 mm upstream of the bottom of the stack, or  on a Y fitting connecting the stack to the building drain or branch.

National Sentence Text: A cleanout shall be provided to permit the cleaning of the piping downstream of an interceptor.
P/T Sentence Text: A cleanout shall be provided to permit the cleaning of the piping immediately downstream of an interceptor.

National Sentence Text: Cleanouts shall be installed so that the cumulative change in direction is not more than 90° between cleanouts in a drip pipe from a food receptacle or in a fixture drain serving a kitchen sink in a non-residential occupancy. (See Note A-2.4.7.1.(9).)
P/T Sentence Text: Every indirect drainage pipe carrying waste from a food receptacle shall have a cleanout access at every change of direction of more than 45°.

National Sentence Text: A fixture outlet pipe, a trap with a removable trap dip, or a separate cleanout shall be used as a cleanout for a fixture drain. (See Note A-2.4.7.1.(10).)
P/T Sentence Text: A cleanout shall be installed on a trap arm serving a kitchen sink as close as practical to the trap outlet and shall be readily accessible.

National Sentence Text: Building drains shall be provided with an additional cleanout for each cumulative horizontal change in direction exceeding 135°.
Except as provided in Sentences 2.4.7.2. to 2.4.7.2.(4), the size and spacing of cleanouts in nominally horizontal pipes of a drainage system shall conform to Table 2.4.7.2.
P/T Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentences  and , on drainage piping of 4 in. size and smaller, the minimum size cleanout opening shall be the same size as the drainage pipe and on drainage piping larger than the 4 in. size, the cleanout opening shall be 4 in. or larger and the maximum spacing between cleanouts on horizontal pipe shall be, in the case of a sink waste pipe, 6 m,  in the case of a horizontal sanitary drainage pipe, or storm drainage pipe, other than a waste pipe from a sink, 15 m, and  in the case of a horizontal sanitary drainage pipe or storm drainage pipe larger than 4 in. size, 30 m.

National Sentence Text: Cleanout fittings for building drains shall be at least 4 inches in size.
The spacing between manholes serving a building sewer 24 inches or less in size shall not exceed 90 m, and over 24 inches in size shall not exceed 150 m.
P/T Sentence Text: The spacing between manholes serving a building sewer, 24 in. or less in size shall not exceed 90 m, and  over 24 in. in size shall not exceed 150 m.

National Sentence Text: Cleanouts that allow rodding in one direction only shall be installed to permit rodding in the direction of flow.
P/T Sentence Text: Cleanouts that allow rodding in one direction only shall be installed to permit rodding in the direction of flow.

National Sentence Text: Where a building sewer connects to another building sewer other than by a manhole, the developed length between the building and the building sewer to which it connects shall not exceed 30 m.
A manhole, including the cover, shall be designed to support all loads imposed upon it.
P/T Sentence Text: A manhole including the cover shall be designed to support all loads imposed upon it.

National Sentence Text: A manhole shall be provided with a cover that provides an airtight seal if located within a building, a rigid ladder of a corrosion-resistant material where the depth exceeds 1 m, and a vent to the exterior if the manhole is located within a building.
P/T Sentence Text: A manhole shall be provided with, a cover which shall provide an airtight seal if located within a building,  a rigid ladder of a corrosion-resistant material where the depth exceeds 1 000 mm, and  a vent to the exterior if the manhole is located within a building.

National Sentence Text: A manhole shall have a minimum horizontal dimension of 1 m, except that the top 1.5 m may be tapered from 1 m down to a minimum of 600 mm at the top.
P/T Sentence Text: A manhole shall have a minimum horizontal dimension of 1 200 mm, except that the top 1 500 mm may be tapered from 1 200 mm down to a minimum of 600 mm at the top.

National Sentence Text: A manhole in a sanitary drainage system shall be channeled to direct the flow of effluent.
P/T Sentence Text: A manhole in a sanitary drainage system shall be channelled to direct the flow of effluent.

National Sentence Text: Cleanouts and access covers shall be located so that their openings are readily accessible for drain cleaning purposes.
P/T Sentence Text: Cleanouts and access covers shall be located so that the openings are readily accessible for drain cleaning purposes.

National Sentence Text: A cleanout shall not be located in a floor assembly in a manner that may constitute a hazard, or used as a floor drain.
P/T Sentence Text: A cleanout shall not be located in a floor assembly in a manner that may constitute a hazard and shall not be used as a floor drain.

National Sentence Text: There shall be no change of direction between a cleanout fitting and the trap that it serves.
P/T Sentence Text: Reserved

National Sentence Text: The piping between a cleanout fitting and the drainage system it serves shall not change direction by more than 45°.
P/T Sentence Text: Each change of direction of the piping between a cleanout fitting and the drainage piping or vent piping that it serves shall be accomplished by using 45° bends.

National Sentence Text: Cleanouts serving fixtures in health care facilities, mortuaries, laboratories and similar occupancies, where contamination by body fluids is likely, shall be located a minimum of 150 mm above the flood level rim of the fixture.
P/T Sentence Text: A cleanout serving a fixture in health care facilities, mortuaries, laboratories and similar occupancies, where contamination by body fluids is likely, shall be located a minimum of 150 mm above the flood level rim of the fixture.

National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Articles 2.4.10.8. and 2.4.10.9., drainage pipes that are 3 inches or less in size shall have a downward slope in the direction of flow of at least 1 in 50. (See Note A-2.4.8.1.(1).)
P/T Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentences  and , every drainage pipe that has a size of 3 in. or less shall have a downward slope in the direction of flow of at least 1 in 50.

National Sentence Text: Except for fixture outlet pipes installed in conformance with Sentence 2.4.5.1.(3), the developed length of fixture outlet pipes shall not exceed 1 200 mm. (See Note A-2.4.8.2.(1).) (See also Note A-2.4.5.1.(2).)
P/T Sentence Text: Except for fixture outlet pipes installed in conformance with Sentence 7.4.5.1.(3), the developed length of every fixture outlet pipe shall not exceed 1 200 mm.

National Sentence Text: A soil-or-waste pipe shall be of a size not less than the size of a vent pipe that is connected to it, or the largest soil-or-waste pipe that drains into it.
P/T Sentence Text: A sanitary drainage pipe may be connected to a pre-engineered waste water heat recovery system that incorporates piping of a lesser size than required by Sentence  provided that it does not convey sewage,  from a sanitary unit, or  that contains solids.

National Sentence Text: Drainage pipes that serve a water closet shall be not less than 3 inches in size.
P/T Sentence Text: The size of every drainage pipe that serves a water closet shall be at least 3 in.

National Sentence Text: Branch and building drains downstream of the third water closet fixture drain connection shall be not less than 4 inches in size.
P/T Sentence Text: The size of every horizontal drainage pipe downstream of the third water closet fixture drain connection shall be at least 4 in.

National Sentence Text: Soil-or-waste stacks that serve more than 6 water closets shall be not less than 4 inches in size.
P/T Sentence Text: The size of every soil stack that serves more than six water closets shall be at least 4 in.

National Sentence Text: Discharge pipes serving a macerating toilet system shall be not less than ¾ inch in size.
P/T Sentence Text: The size of the discharge pipe serving a macerating toilet system shall be at least ¾ in.

National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence 2.4.9.3.(2), the size of fixture outlet pipes shall conform to Table 2.4.9.3.
P/T Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence , the size of every fixture outlet pipe shall conform to Table 7.4.9.3.

National Sentence Text: The part of the fixture outlet pipe that is common to 3 compartments of a sink shall be one size larger than the largest fixture outlet pipe of the compartments that it serves. (See Note A-2.4.9.3.(2).)
P/T Sentence Text: The part of the fixture outlet pipe that is common to three compartments of a sink shall be one size larger than the largest fixture outlet pipe of the compartments that it serves.

National Sentence Text: Where clothes washers do not drain to a laundry tray, the trap inlet shall be fitted with a vertical standpipe that is not less than 600 mm long measured from the trap weir and terminates above the flood level rim of the clothes washer. (See Note A-2.4.9.3.(3).)
P/T Sentence Text: Where clothes washers do not drain to a laundry tray, the trap inlet shall be fitted with a vertical standpipe that is not less than 600 mm long measured from the trap weir and the top of the standpipe shall terminate above the flood level rim of the clothes washer it serves.

National Article Title: Size of Building Drain and Building Sewer
National Sentence Text: Building drains and building sewers connected to the public sewer system downstream of the main cleanout (see Sentence 2.4.7.1.(6)) shall be not less than 4 inches in size.
P/T Article Title: 7.4.9.4. Minimum Size of Building Drains and Sewers
P/T Sentence Text: Every sanitary building drain and every sanitary building sewer shall be at least 4 in. in size.

National Sentence Text: The hydraulic load on a pipe is the total load from every fixture that is connected to the system upstream of the pipe, every fixture for which provision is made for future connection upstream of the pipe, and all roofs and paved surfaces that drain into the system upstream of the pipe.
P/T Sentence Text: The hydraulic load on a pipe is the total load from, every fixture that is connected to the system upstream of the pipe,  every fixture for which provision is made for future connection upstream of the pipe, and  all roofs and paved surfaces that drain into the system upstream of the pipe.

National Sentence Text: The hydraulic load from a fixture that is listed in Table 2.4.9.3. is the number of fixture units set forth in the Table.
P/T Sentence Text: The hydraulic load from a fixture that is listed in Table 7.4.9.3. is the number of fixture units set forth in the Table.

National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence 2.4.10.2.(1), the hydraulic load from a fixture that is not listed in Table 2.4.9.3. is the number of fixture units set forth in Table 2.4.10.2. for the trap of the size that serves the fixture.
P/T Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence , the hydraulic load from a fixture that is not listed in Table 7.4.9.3. is the number of fixture units set forth in Table 7.4.10.2. for the trap of the size that serves the fixture.

National Article Title: Hydraulic Loads from Fixtures with a Continuous Flow
National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence 2.4.10.3.(2), the hydraulic load from a fixture that produces a continuous flow, such as a pump or an air-conditioning fixture, is 31.7 fixture units for each litre per second of flow.
P/T Article Title: 7.4.10.3. Hydraulic Loads from Fixtures with Continuous or Semi-Continuous Flow
P/T Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence , the hydraulic load from a fixture that produces a continuous flow, such as a pump or an air-conditioning fixture, is 31.7 fixture units for each litre per second of flow.

National Article Title: Hydraulic Loads from Fixtures with a Continuous Flow
National Sentence Text: Where a fixture or equipment that produces a continuous or semi-continuous flow drains to a combined sewer or to a storm sewer, the hydraulic load from the fixture is 900 L for each litre per second of flow.
P/T Article Title: 7.4.10.3. Hydraulic Loads from Fixtures with Continuous or Semi-Continuous Flow
P/T Sentence Text: Where a fixture or equipment that produces a continuous or semi-continuous flow drains to a storm drainage system, the hydraulic load from the fixture is 900 litres for each litre per second of flow.

National Article Title: Hydraulic Loads from Fixtures with a Continuous Flow
National Sentence Text: The hydraulic load from a fixture or equipment that produces a semi-continuous flow shall conform to Table 2.4.10.12.
P/T Article Title: 7.4.10.3. Hydraulic Loads from Fixtures with Continuous or Semi-Continuous Flow
P/T Sentence Text: The hydraulic load from a fixture or equipment that produces a semi-continuous flow shall conform to Table 7.4.10.3.

National Article Title: Hydraulic Loads from Roofs or Paved Surfaces
National Sentence Text: Flow control roof drains may be installed, provided the maximum drain down time does not exceed 24 h, the roof structure is designed to carry the load of the stored water, one or more scuppers are installed not more than 30 m apart along the perimeter of the building so that up to 200% of the 15-minute rainfall intensity can be handled, and the maximum depth of controlled water is limited to 150 mm, they are located not more than 15 m from the edge of the roof and not more than 30 m from adjacent drains, and there is at least one drain for each 900 m2.
P/T Article Title: 7.4.10.4. Hydraulic Loads from Roofs or Paved Surfaces
P/T Sentence Text: Flow control roof drains may be installed provided, the maximum drain down time does not exceed 24 h,  the roof structure is designed to carry the load of the stored water,  one or more scuppers are installed not more than 30 m apart along the perimeter of the building so that,  the scuppers are designed to handle at least 200% of the 15-minute rainfall intensity, and  the maximum depth of controlled water is limited to 150 mm,  they are located not more than 15 m from the edge of the roof and not more than 30 m from adjacent drains, and  there is at least one drain for each 900 m2.

National Article Title: Hydraulic Loads from Roofs or Paved Surfaces
National Sentence Text: Hydraulic loads, in litres per second, for flow control roof drains and restricted paved area drains shall be determined according to rain intensity-duration frequency curves as compiled by Environment Canada using 25-year frequencies.

National Article Title: Hydraulic Loads on Storm or Combined Building Drains or Sewers
National Sentence Text: The hydraulic load that is drained to a storm building drain, a storm building sewer or a combined building sewer shall conform to Table 2.4.10.9.
P/T Article Title: 7.4.10.9. Hydraulic Loads on Horizontal Storm Drains
P/T Sentence Text: The hydraulic load that is drained to a horizontal storm drainage pipe shall conform to Table 7.4.10.9., based on the size and slope.

National Sentence Text: The hydraulic load that is drained to a roof gutter shall conform to Table 2.4.10.10.

No change in the size of a leader with a nominally horizontal offset is required if the offset is located immediately under the roof, is not more than 6 m long, and has a slope of not less than 1 in 50.
P/T Sentence Text: No change in the size of a rain leader with a nominally horizontal offset is required if the offset, is located immediately under the roof,  is not more than 6 m long, and  has a slope not less than 1 in 50.

National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentences 2.4.10.4. and 2.4.10.4.(2), and Article 2.4.10.9., storm sewers may be designed in accordance with good engineering practice.
Except as provided in Sentences 2.5.1.1. and 2.5.1.1.(4), traps shall be protected by a vent pipe.
P/T Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentences  and , every trap shall be protected by a vent pipe.

National Sentence Text: Fixtures with fixture outlet pipes less than 2 inches in size shall be separately vented or separately circuit-vented.
P/T Sentence Text: Fixtures with fixture outlet pipes less than 2 in. in size shall be separately vented or separately circuit vented.

National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentences 2.5.3.1. and 2.5.3.1.(5), a relief vent shall be connected to the branch that forms part of a circuit-vented system, downstream of the connection of the most downstream circuit-vented fixture.
P/T Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentences  and , a relief vent shall be connected to the branch that forms part of a circuit vented system, downstream of the connection of the most downstream circuit vented fixture.

National Sentence Text: A soil-or-waste pipe having a hydraulic load not greater than 6 fixture units is permitted to act as a relief vent for a branch that is circuit-vented.
P/T Sentence Text: A soil or waste pipe having a hydraulic load not greater than six fixture units may act as a relief vent for a branch that is being circuit vented.

National Sentence Text: A symmetrically connected relief vent is permitted to serve as a combined relief vent for a maximum of 2 branches that are circuit-vented, provided there are not more than 8 circuit-vented fixtures connected between the combined relief vent and each circuit vent.
P/T Sentence Text: A symmetrically connected relief vent may serve as a combined relief vent for a maximum of two branches that are circuit vented, provided there are not more than eight circuit vented fixtures connected between the combined relief vent and each circuit vent.

National Sentence Text: A soil-or-waste pipe is permitted to serve as an additional circuit vent in accordance with Sentence 2.5.3.1.(6), provided the soil-or-waste pipe is sized as a wet vent in conformance with Article 2.5.8.1. and is not less than 2 inches in size.
P/T Sentence Text: A soil or waste pipe may serve as an additional circuit vent in accordance with Sentence  provided that the soil or waste pipe is sized as a wet vent in conformance with Article 7.5.8.1. and is not less than 2 in. in size.

National Sentence Text: Connections to circuit vents and additional circuit vents in accordance with Sentence 2.5.3.1. shall conform to Sentence 2.5.4.5.(1).
P/T Sentence Text: Connections to circuit vents and additional circuit vents in accordance with Sentence  shall conform to Sentence 7.5.4.5.(1).

National Sentence Text: A circuit-vented branch, including the fixture drain downstream of the circuit vent connection, shall be sized in accordance with Article 2.4.10.7., except that it shall be not less than 2 inches, where traps less than 2 inches in size are circuit-vented, or 3 inches, where traps 2 inches in size or larger are circuit-vented.
P/T Sentence Text: A circuit vented branch, including the fixture drain downstream of the circuit vent connection, shall be sized in accordance with Articles 7.4.10.7. and 7.4.10.8., except that it shall be not less than, 2 in., where traps less than 2 in. in size are circuit vented, or  3 in., where traps 2 in. in size or larger are circuit vented.

National Sentence Text: The hydraulic load on a circuit vent shall include the hydraulic load from fixtures connected to the branch served by the circuit vent, but shall not include the hydraulic load from fixtures permitted by Sentences 2.5.3.1.(3), 2.5.3.1. and 2.5.3.1.(5).
P/T Sentence Text: The hydraulic load on a circuit vent shall include the hydraulic load from fixtures connected to the branch served by the circuit vent, but shall not include the hydraulic load from fixtures permitted by Sentences ,  and .

National Sentence Text: The upper end of every soil-or-waste stack shall terminate in a stack vent.
P/T Sentence Text: The upper end of every soil or waste stack shall terminate in a stack vent and the stack vent shall terminate in open air outside the building, or connect directly or through a header to another stack vent or vent stack that does terminate in open air outside the building.

National Sentence Text: A soil-or-waste stack that serves as a wet vent does not require a vent stack.
P/T Sentence Text: A soil or waste stack that serves as a wet vent does not require a vent stack.

National Sentence Text: Fixtures are permitted to be connected to a vent stack, provided the total hydraulic load of the connected fixtures does not exceed 8 fixture units, at least one fixture is connected to a vertical portion of the vent stack and upstream of any other fixtures, no other fixture is connected downstream of a water closet, all fixtures are located in the lowest storey served by the vent stack, and the section of the vent pipe that acts as a wet vent conforms to the requirements regarding wet vents.
P/T Sentence Text: Fixtures may be connected to a vent stack provided, the total hydraulic load of the connected fixtures does not exceed eight fixture units,  at least one fixture is connected to a vertical portion of the vent stack and upstream of any other fixtures,  no other fixture is connected downstream of a water closet,  all fixtures are located in the lowest storey served by the vent stack, and  the section of the vent pipe that acts as a wet vent conforms to the requirements regarding wet vents.

National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence 2.5.4.3.(4), where a soil-or-waste stack receives the discharge from fixtures located on more than 11 storeys, a yoke vent shall be installed for each section of 5 storeys or part thereof counted from the top down, and at or immediately above each offset or double offset.
P/T Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence , where a soil or waste stack receives the discharge from fixtures located on more than 11 storeys, a yoke vent shall be, installed for each section of 5 storeys or part of them counted from the top down,  installed at or immediately above each offset or double offset, and  sized in accordance with Sentence 7.5.7.5.(1).

National Sentence Text: The yoke vent shall be connected to the soil-or-waste stack by means of a drainage fitting at or immediately below the lowest soil-or-waste pipe from the lowest storey of the sections described in Sentence 2.5.4.3.(1).
P/T Sentence Text: The yoke vent shall be connected to the soil or waste stack by means of a drainage fitting at or immediately below the lowest soil or waste pipe from the lowest storey of the sections described in Sentence .

National Sentence Text: The yoke vent shall connect to the vent stack at least 1 m above the floor level of the lowest storey in the section described in Sentence 2.5.4.3.(1).
P/T Sentence Text: The yoke vent shall connect to the vent stack at least 1 000 mm above the floor level of the lowest storey in the section described in Sentence .

National Sentence Text: A yoke vent need not be installed provided the soil-or-waste stack is interconnected with the vent stack in each storey of the section in which fixtures are located by means of a vent pipe equal in size to the branch or fixture drain or 2 inches in size, whichever is smaller.
P/T Sentence Text: A yoke vent need not be installed provided the soil or waste stack is interconnected with the vent stack in each storey of the section in which fixtures are located by means of a vent pipe equal in size to the branch or fixture drain or 2 in. in size, whichever is smaller.

National Sentence Text: Every sump that receives sewage shall be provided with a vent pipe that is connected to the top of the sump. (See Article 2.5.7.7. for sizing of these vents.)
P/T Sentence Text: Every sump or tank that receives sanitary sewage shall be provided with a vent pipe that is connected to the top of the sump or tank.

National Sentence Text: Every oil interceptor shall be provided with 2 vent pipes that connect to the interceptor at opposite ends, extend independently to outside air, and terminate not less than 2 m above ground and at elevations differing by at least 300 mm.
P/T Sentence Text: Every oil interceptor shall be provided with 2 vent pipes that, connect to the interceptor at opposite ends,  extend independently to open air,  terminate not less than 2 000 mm above ground and at elevations differing by at least 300 mm, and  do not connect to each other or any other vent pipe.

National Sentence Text: Where a secondary receiver for oil is installed in conjunction with an oil interceptor, it shall be vented in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations, and the vent pipe shall in no case be less than 1½ inches in size, extend independently to outside air, and terminate not less than 2 m above ground.
P/T Sentence Text: Where a secondary receiver for oil is installed in conjunction with an oil interceptor, it shall be vented in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations, and the vent pipe shall,  in no case be less than 1½ in. in size,  extend independently to open air, and  terminate not less than 2 000 mm above ground.

National Sentence Text: The vent pipes referred to in Sentence 2.5.5.2. are permitted to be one size smaller than the largest connected drainage pipe but not less than 1¼ inches in size, or can be sized in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations.
P/T Sentence Text: The vent pipes referred to in Sentence  are permitted to be one size smaller than the largest connected drainage pipe but not less than 1¼ in. in size, or can be sized in accordance with the manufacturer s recommendations.

National Sentence Text: A vent pipe that serves an oil interceptor and is located outside a building shall be not less than 3 inches in size in areas where it may be subject to frost closure.
P/T Sentence Text: Every vent pipe that serves an oil or grease interceptor and is located outside a building shall be not less than 3 in. in size in areas where it may be subject to frost closure.

National Article Title: Venting of Drain Piping and Dilution Tanks for Corrosive Waste
National Sentence Text: Venting systems for drain piping or dilution tanks conveying corrosive waste shall extend independently and terminate in outside air. (See Article 2.5.7.7. for sizing of these vents.)
P/T Sentence Text: Where an acid waste dilution tank is installed, it shall be provided with a vent pipe connected at the top of the tank and that is sized in accordance with Article 7.5.7.7.

National Article Title: Venting of Drain Piping and Dilution Tanks for Corrosive Waste
National Sentence Text: Venting systems for drain piping or dilution tanks conveying corrosive waste shall extend independently and terminate in outside air. (See Article 2.5.7.7. for sizing of these vents.)
P/T Article Title: 7.5.5.3. Venting of Corrosive Drain Piping and Dilution Tanks
P/T Sentence Text: Venting systems for drain piping or dilution tanks conveying corrosive waste shall extend independently and terminate in open air.

National Sentence Text: Where a building trap is installed, a fresh air inlet not less than 4 inches in size shall be connected upstream and within 1.2 m of the building trap and downstream of any other connection. (See Note A-2.4.5.4.(1).)
P/T Sentence Text: Where a building trap is installed, a fresh air inlet not less than 4 in. in size shall be connected upstream and within 1 200 mm of the building trap and downstream of any other connection.

National Sentence Text: Except as required in Sentence 2.5.7.7.(2), where a plumbing system is installed in a building, every storey in which plumbing is or may be installed, including the basement of a single-family dwelling, shall have extended into it or passing through it a vent pipe that is at least 1½ inches in size for the provision of future connections.
P/T Sentence Text: Except as required in Sentence 7.5.7.7.(2), where a plumbing system is installed in a building, every storey in which plumbing is or may be installed, including the basement of the building, shall have extended into it or passing through it a vent pipe that is at least 1½ in. in size for the provision of future connections.

National Sentence Text: Vent pipes shall be installed without depressions in which moisture can collect.
P/T Sentence Text: Every vent pipe shall be installed without depression in which moisture can collect.

National Sentence Text: Vent pipes shall be installed in a nominally vertical position where it is practical to do so.
P/T Sentence Text: Every vent pipe in a plumbing system shall be installed so as to be direct as possible to a vent stack or open air, as the case may be, and so that any horizontal run below the flood level of the fixture to which the vent pipe is installed is eliminated where structurally possible.

National Sentence Text: Except for wet vents, where a vent pipe is connected to a nominally horizontal soil-or-waste pipe, the connection shall be above the horizontal centre line of the soil-or-waste pipe. (See Note A-2.5.6.2.(2).)
P/T Sentence Text: Except for wet vents, where a vent pipe is connected to a nominally horizontal soil or waste pipe, the connection shall be above the horizontal centre line of the soil or waste pipe.

National Sentence Text: Unused vent pipes installed for future connections shall be permanently capped with an end cleanout or an adapter and plug.
P/T Sentence Text: Unused vent pipes installed for future connections shall be permanently capped with an end cleanout or an adapter and plug.

National Sentence Text: The trap arm of water closets, of S-trap standards or of any other fixture that also discharges vertically and depends on siphonic action for its proper functioning shall not have a cumulative change in direction of more than 225°. (See Note A-2.5.6.3.(2).)
P/T Sentence Text: The trap arm of water closets, S-trap standards or any other fixture that also discharges vertically and depends on siphonic action for its proper functioning shall not have a cumulative change in direction of more than 225°.

National Sentence Text: The maximum length of every trap arm shall conform to Table 2.5.6.3.
P/T Sentence Text: The maximum length and minimum slope of every trap arm shall conform to Table 7.5.6.3.

National Article Title: Connection of Vents above Fixtures Served
National Sentence Text: No vent pipe shall be connected in such a manner that a blockage in a soil-or-waste pipe would cause waste to drain through the vent pipe to the drainage system.
P/T Article Title: 7.5.6.4. Connection of Vents Above Fixtures Served
P/T Sentence Text: No vent pipe shall be connected in such a manner that a blockage in a soil or waste pipe would cause waste to drain through the vent pipe to the drainage system.

National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence 2.5.6.5.(3), the upper end of every vent pipe that is not terminated in outside air shall be connected to a venting system that terminates through a roof to outside air.
P/T Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence , the upper end of every vent pipe that is not terminated in open air shall be connected to a venting system that terminates through a roof to open air.

National Sentence Text: The upper end of every vent pipe that is terminated in outside air, other than a vent pipe that serves an oil interceptor or a fresh air inlet, shall be extended above the roof.
P/T Sentence Text: The upper end of every vent pipe that is terminated in open air, other than a vent pipe that serves an oil interceptor or a fresh air inlet, shall be extended above the roof.

National Sentence Text: A vent pipe is permitted to be erected outside a building, provided that no single change in direction of the vent pipe exceeds 45°, all parts of the vent pipe are nominally vertical, in areas where the vent pipe may be subject to frost closure, it is increased to not less than 3 inches in size before penetrating a wall or roof, and where the building is 4 storeys or less in height, the vent pipe terminates above the roof of the building.
P/T Sentence Text: Where a vent pipe is installed as a result of additions or alterations to a plumbing system in an existing building, the vent pipe may be erected outside the building, provided that,  no single change of direction of the vent pipe exceeds 45°,  all parts of the vent pipe are nominally vertical,  the vent pipe is increased to not less than 3 in. in size before penetrating a wall or roof, and  where the building is 4 storeys or less in height, the vent pipe terminates above the roof of the building.

National Sentence Text: Where a vent pipe passes through a roof, it shall be terminated high enough to prevent the entry of roof drainage but not less than 150 mm above the roof or above the surface of storm water, which could pond on the roof (see Note A-2.5.6.5.(4)), and be provided with flashing to prevent the entry of water between the vent pipe and the roof (see Article 2.2.10.14.).
P/T Sentence Text: Where a vent pipe passes through a roof, it shall, be terminated high enough to prevent the entry of roof drainage but not less than 150 mm above the roof or above the surface of storm water, which could pond on the roof, and  be equipped with flashing to prevent the entry of water between the vent pipe and the roof or the wall.

National Sentence Text: The size of every vent pipe shall conform to Table 2.5.7.1.
P/T Sentence Text: The size of every vent pipe shall conform to Table 7.5.7.1.

National Sentence Text: The size of a branch vent, stack vent, vent stack or vent header shall be not less than the size of the vent pipe to which it is connected.
P/T Sentence Text: The size of a branch vent, stack vent, vent stack or header shall be not less than the size of the vent pipe to which it is connected.

National Sentence Text: Sanitary building drains shall be provided with at least one vent that is not less than 3 inches in size.
P/T Sentence Text: Every sanitary building drain shall terminate at its upstream end in a stack of at least 3 in. size.

National Article Title: Additional Circuit Vents and Relief Vents
National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Article 2.5.7.1. and Sentence 2.5.3.1.(7), the minimum size of an additional circuit vent or relief vent installed in conjunction with a circuit vent is permitted to be one size smaller than the required size of the circuit vent, but need not be larger than 2 inches.
P/T Article Title: 7.5.7.3. Additional Circuit Vents and Relief Vents
P/T Sentence Text: Except as provided in Article 7.5.7.1. and in Sentence 7.5.3.1.(7), the minimum size of an additional circuit vent or relief vent installed in conjunction with a circuit vent is permitted to be one size smaller than the required size of the circuit vent, but need not be larger than 2 in.

National Sentence Text: Yoke vents required by Sentence 2.5.4.3. are permitted to be one size smaller than the size of the smallest pipe to which they are connected.
P/T Sentence Text: Yoke vents required by Sentence 7.5.4.3. are permitted to be one size smaller than the size of the smallest pipe to which they are connected.

National Sentence Text: The minimum size of a vent pipe that serves a manhole within a building shall be 2 inches.
P/T Sentence Text: The minimum size of a vent pipe that serves a manhole within a building shall be 2 in.

National Article Title: Vents for Sewage Sumps, Dilution Tanks and Macerating Toilet
National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentences 2.5.7.7. and 2.5.7.7.(3), the minimum size of the vent pipe for a sewage sump or dilution tank shall be one size smaller than the size of the largest branch or fixture drain draining to the sump.
P/T Article Title: 7.5.7.7. Vents for Sanitary Sewage Sumps or Tanks, Dilution Tanks and Macerating Toilet Systems
P/T Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentences  and , the minimum size of the vent pipe for a sanitary sewage sump or tank, or dilution tank shall be one size smaller than the size of the largest branch or fixture drain draining to the sump or tank.

National Article Title: Vents for Sewage Sumps, Dilution Tanks and Macerating Toilet
National Sentence Text: The size of every vent pipe for a sewage sump or dilution tank shall be not less than 2 inches, but need not be greater than 4 inches.
P/T Article Title: 7.5.7.7. Vents for Sanitary Sewage Sumps or Tanks, Dilution Tanks and Macerating Toilet Systems
P/T Sentence Text: The size of every vent pipe for a sanitary sewage sump or tank, or dilution tank shall be not less than 2 in., but need not be greater than 4 in.

National Article Title: Vents for Sewage Sumps, Dilution Tanks and Macerating Toilet
National Sentence Text: The size of a vent pipe for a macerating toilet system with a sump shall be not less than 1½ inches.
P/T Article Title: 7.5.7.7. Vents for Sanitary Sewage Sumps or Tanks, Dilution Tanks and Macerating Toilet Systems
P/T Sentence Text: The size of every vent pipe for a macerating toilet system with a sump or tank shall be not less than 1 ½ in.

National Article Title: Hydraulic Loads Draining to Wet Vents
National Sentence Text: The hydraulic load that drains to a wet vent shall conform to Table 2.5.8.1.
P/T Article Title: 7.5.8.1. Hydraulic Loads Draining to Wet Vents
P/T Sentence Text: The hydraulic load that drains to a wet vent shall conform to Table 7.5.8.1.

National Article Title: Hydraulic Loads Draining to Wet Vents
National Sentence Text: When determining the size of a wet vent, the hydraulic load from the most downstream fixture or symmetrically connected fixtures shall not be included. (See Note A-2.5.8.1.(2).)
P/T Article Title: 7.5.8.1. Hydraulic Loads Draining to Wet Vents
P/T Sentence Text: When determining the size of a wet vent, the hydraulic load from the most downstream fixture or symmetrically connected fixtures shall not be included.

National Sentence Text: The size of individual vents and dual vents shall be determined using Table 2.5.7.1. based on the largest trap served.
P/T Sentence Text: The size of individual vents and dual vents shall be determined using Table 7.5.7.1. according to the largest trap served.

National Article Title: Branch Vents, Vent Headers, Continuous Vents and Circuit Vents
National Sentence Text: For the purposes of Table 2.5.8.3., the length of a branch vent shall be its developed length from the most distant soil-or-waste pipe connection to a vent stack, stack vent, vent header or outside air.
P/T Article Title: 7.5.8.3. Branch Vents, Headers, Continuous Vents and Circuit Vents
P/T Sentence Text: For the purposes of Table 7.5.8.3., the length of a branch vent shall be its developed length from the most distant soil or waste pipe connection to a vent stack, stack vent, header or open air.

National Article Title: Branch Vents, Vent Headers, Continuous Vents and Circuit Vents
National Sentence Text: For the purposes of Table 2.5.8.3., the length of a vent header shall be its developed length from the most distant soil-or-waste pipe connection to outside air.
P/T Article Title: 7.5.8.3. Branch Vents, Headers, Continuous Vents and Circuit Vents
P/T Sentence Text: For the purposes of Table 7.5.8.3., the length of a header shall be its developed length from the most distant soil or waste pipe connection to open air.

National Article Title: Branch Vents, Vent Headers, Continuous Vents and Circuit Vents
National Sentence Text: For the purposes of Table 2.5.8.3., the length of a circuit vent shall be its developed length from the horizontal soil-or-waste pipe connection to a vent stack, stack vent, vent header or outside air.
P/T Article Title: 7.5.8.3. Branch Vents, Headers, Continuous Vents and Circuit Vents
P/T Sentence Text: For the purposes of Table 7.5.8.3., the length of a circuit vent shall be its developed length from the horizontal soil or waste pipe connection to a vent stack, stack vent, header or open air.

National Sentence Text: A vent stack or stack vent shall be sized in accordance with Table 2.5.8.4. based on the length of the vent stack or stack vent, and the total hydraulic load that is drained to the lowest section of soil-or-waste stack or stacks served by the vent pipe, plus any additional vent loads connected to the vent stack or stack vent.
P/T Sentence Text: A vent stack, or stack vent shall be sized in accordance with Table 7.5.8.4. based on, the length of the vent stack or stack vent, and  the total hydraulic load that is drained to the lowest section of soil or waste stack or stacks served by the vent pipe, plus any additional vent loads connected to the vent stack or stack vent.

National Sentence Text: For the purposes of Table 2.5.8.4., the length of a stack vent or vent stack shall be its developed length from its lower end to outside air.
P/T Sentence Text: For the purposes of Table 7.5.8.4., the length of a stack vent or vent stack shall be its developed length from its lower end to open air.

National Sentence Text: The minimum size of a vent stack or stack vent shall be one-half the size of the soil-or-waste stack at its base.
P/T Sentence Text: The minimum size of vent stack or stack vent shall be one-half the size of the soil or waste stack at its base.

National Sentence Text: A stack vent serving a wet vent stack that is over 4 storeys high shall extend the full size of the wet vent to outside air.
P/T Sentence Text: A stack vent serving a wet vent stack that is over 4 storeys high shall extend the full size of the wet vent to open air.

National Sentence Text: When sizing an additional circuit vent, offset relief vent, relief vent, yoke vent, and the vent pipe for an interceptor, dilution tank, sewage tank, sump, or manhole, length is not taken into consideration.
P/T Sentence Text: When sizing an additional circuit vent, offset relief vent, relief vent, yoke vent and the vent pipe for an interceptor, dilution tank, sanitary sewage tank or sump, or manhole, length is not taken into consideration.

National Article Title: Air Admittance Valve as a Vent Terminal
National Sentence Text: Individual vents and dual vents are permitted to terminate with a connection to an air admittance valve as provided in Articles 2.5.9.2. and 2.5.9.3. (See also Sentence 2.2.10.16.(1).)
P/T Article Title: 7.5.9.1. Air Admittance Valve as a Vent Terminal
P/T Sentence Text: Individual vents and dual vents are permitted to terminate with a connection to an air admittance valve as provided in Articles 7.5.9.2. and 7.5.9.3.

National Sentence Text: Air admittance valves shall only be used to vent fixtures located in island counters, fixtures that may be affected by frost closure of the vent due to local climatic conditions, fixtures in one- and two-family dwellings undergoing renovation, or installations where connection to a vent may not be practical.
P/T Sentence Text: Air admittance valves shall only be used to vent, fixtures in buildings undergoing renovation, and  installations where connection to a vent may not be practical.

National Sentence Text: Air admittance valves shall be located not less than 100 mm above the fixture drain being vented, within the maximum developed length permitted for the vent, and not less than 150 mm above insulation materials.
P/T Sentence Text: The air admittance valves shall be located, above the flood level rim of the fixture it serves,  within the maximum developed length permitted for the vent,  not less than 150 mm above insulation materials, and  installed in a location not subject to back pressure.

National Sentence Text: Air admittance valves shall be installed in accordance with the manufacturer's installation instructions.
P/T Sentence Text: Air admittance valves shall be installed in accordance with the manufacturer s installation instructions.

National Sentence Text: Air admittance valves shall be rated for the size of vent pipe to which they are connected.
P/T Sentence Text: Air admittance valves shall be rated for the size of vent pipe to which they are connected.

National Sentence Text: Fixtures supplied with separate hot and cold water controls shall have the hot water control on the left and the cold on the right.
P/T Sentence Text: Every fixture supplied with separate hot and cold water controls shall have the hot water control on the left and the cold on the right.

National Sentence Text: In a hot water distribution system of a developed length of more than 30 m or supplying more than 4 storeys, the water temperature shall be maintained by recirculation, or a self-regulating heat tracing system.
P/T Sentence Text: In a hot water distribution system of a developed length of more than 30 m or supplying more than 4 storeys, the water temperature shall be maintained by,  recirculation, or  a self-regulating heat tracing system.

National Sentence Text: A water distribution system shall be installed so that the system can be drained or blown out with air.
P/T Sentence Text: A water distribution system shall be installed so that the system can be drained or blown out with air and outlets for this purpose shall be provided.

National Sentence Text: Water service pipes shall be provided with an accessible shut-off valve located as close as possible to where the water service pipe enters the building.
P/T Sentence Text: A building control valve shall be provided, on every water service pipe at the location where the water service pipe enters the building, or  on the water distribution system at a location immediately downstream of the point of entry treatment unit, where the building is served by a point of entry treatment unit located in the building.

National Sentence Text: Pipes that convey water from a gravity water tank or from a private water supply system shall be fitted with a shut-off valve at the source of supply.
P/T Sentence Text: Every pipe that is supplied with water from a tank on the property that is a gravity water tank or a tank of a drinking water system shall be provided with a shut-off valve located close to the tank.

National Sentence Text: In buildings of other than residential occupancy, shut-off valves shall be provided on the water supply to every fixture, or any group of fixtures in the same room, except as provided in Sentence 2.6.1.3.(4).
Water closets shall be provided with a shut-off valve on their water supply pipe.
P/T Sentence Text: Every water closet shall be provided with a shut-off valve on its water supply pipe.

National Sentence Text: Pipes that supply water to a hot water tank shall be provided with a shut-off valve located close to the tank.
P/T Sentence Text: Every water pipe that supplies a hot water tank, pressure vessel, plumbing appliance or water using device shall be provided with a shut-off valve located close to the tank, pressure vessel, plumbing appliance or water using device.

National Sentence Text: Flushing devices that serve water closets or urinals shall have sufficient capacity and be adjusted to deliver at each operation a volume of water that will thoroughly flush the fixture or fixtures they serve.
P/T Sentence Text: Every flushing device that serves a water closet or one or more urinals shall have sufficient capacity and be adjusted to deliver at each operation a volume of water that will thoroughly flush the fixture or fixtures that it serves.

National Sentence Text: Where a manually operated flushing device is installed, it shall serve only one fixture.
P/T Sentence Text: Where a manually operated flushing device is installed, it shall serve only one fixture.

National Sentence Text: Thermostat controls for electric storage-type service water heaters shall be set at a temperature of 60°C. (See Note A-2.6.1.12.(1).)

In addition to the requirements in Sentence 2.6.1.7.(2), the hot water tank of a storage-type service water heater shall be equipped with a pressure-relief valve designed to open when the water pressure in the tank reaches the rated working pressure of the tank, and so located that the pressure in the tank shall not exceed the pressure at the relief valve by more than 35 kPa under any condition of flow within the distribution system.
P/T Sentence Text: Every pressure vessel that is part of a plumbing system or connected to a plumbing system shall be equipped with a pressure relief valve designed to open when the water pressure in the tank reaches the rated working pressure of the tank, and so located that the pressure in the tank shall not exceed 1 100 kPa or one-half the maximum test pressure sustained by the tank, whichever is the lesser.

National Sentence Text: The hot water tank of a storage-type service water heater shall be equipped with a temperature-relief valve with a temperature-sensing element located within the top 150 mm of the tank, and designed to open and discharge sufficient water from the tank to keep the temperature of the water in the tank from exceeding 99°C under all operating conditions.
P/T Sentence Text: Every hot water tank of a storage-type service water heater shall be equipped with a temperature relief valve with a temperature sensing element, located within the top 150 mm of the tank, and  designed to open and discharge sufficient water from the tank to keep the temperature of the water in the tank from exceeding 99°C under all operating conditions.

National Sentence Text: Indirect service water heaters shall be equipped with a pressure-relief valve, and a temperature-relief valve on every storage tank that forms part of the system.
P/T Sentence Text: Every indirect service water heater shall be equipped with,  a pressure relief valve, and  a temperature relief valve on every storage tank that forms part of the system.

National Sentence Text: No shut-off valve shall be installed on the pipe between any tank and the relief valves or on the discharge lines from such relief valves.
P/T Sentence Text: No shut-off valve shall be installed on the pipe between any tank and the relief valves or on the discharge lines from such relief valves.

National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence 2.6.2.1.(2), connections to potable water systems shall be designed and installed so that non-potable water or substances that may render the water non-potable cannot enter the system.
P/T Sentence Text: Connections to potable water systems shall be designed and installed so that non-potable water or substances that may render the water non-potable cannot enter the system.

National Sentence Text: A water treatment device or apparatus shall not be installed unless it can be demonstrated that the device or apparatus will not introduce substances into the system that may endanger health.

Potable water connections to fixtures, tanks, vats or other devices not subject to pressure above atmospheric and containing other than potable water shall be installed so as to prevent back-siphonage in conformance with Sentence 2.6.2.2.(2).
P/T Sentence Text: Every potable water system that supplies a fixture or tank that is not subject to pressures above atmospheric shall be protected against back-siphonage by a backflow preventer.

National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence 2.6.2.10.(2), back-siphonage shall be prevented by the installation of an air gap, an atmospheric vacuum breaker, a pressure vacuum breaker, a spill-resistant pressure vacuum breaker, a hose connection vacuum breaker, a dual check valve backflow preventer with atmospheric port, a double check valve assembly, a reduced pressure principle backflow preventer, a dual check valve backflow preventer, a laboratory faucet type vacuum breaker, or a dual check valve backflow preventer with vent.

Potable water connections to fixtures, tanks, vats, boilers or other devices containing other than potable water and subject to pressure above atmospheric shall be arranged to prevent backflow caused by back pressure in conformance with Sentences 2.6.2.3. and 2.6.2.3.(3).
P/T Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence  and Articles 7.6.2.4. to 7.6.2.6., where a backflow preventer is required by this Subsection, the backflow preventer shall be selected, installed and tested in conformance with CSA B64.10, "Selection and Installation of Backflow Preventers".

National Sentence Text: Backflow caused by back pressure of toxic substances into a potable water system shall be prevented by the installation of an air gap, or a reduced pressure principle backflow preventer.
P/T Sentence Text: Tank type water closet valves shall be provided with a back-siphonage preventer in conformance with Sentence 7.2.10.10.(2).

National Sentence Text: A backflow preventer shall not be required in residential full flow-through fire sprinkler/standpipe systems in which the pipes and fittings are constructed of potable water system materials.
P/T Sentence Text: A backflow preventer shall not be required in a residential full flow through fire sprinkler system, in which the pipe and fittings are constructed of potable water system materials.

National Sentence Text: No private water supply system shall be interconnected with a public water supply system.
A newly installed part of a potable water system shall be cleaned and then flushed with potable water before the system is put into operation.
P/T Sentence Text: A newly installed part of a potable water system shall be cleaned and then flushed with potable water before the system is put into operation. (See Appendix A.)

National Sentence Text: Air gaps shall not be located in a noxious environment.
P/T Sentence Text: An air gap shall not be located in a noxious environment.

National Sentence Text: Air gaps shall be not less than 25 mm high and at least twice the diameter of the opening of the water supply outlet in height. (See Note A-2.6.2.9.(2).)
P/T Sentence Text: Every air gap shall be not less than 25 mm high and at least twice the diameter of the opening of the water supply outlet in height.

National Sentence Text: Where the critical level is not marked on an atmospheric vacuum breaker, pressure vacuum breaker, or spill-resistant pressure vacuum breaker, the critical level shall be taken as the lowest point on the device.
P/T Sentence Text: Where the critical level is not marked on an atmospheric vacuum breaker, pressure vacuum breaker or spill-resistant pressure vacuum breaker, the critical level shall be taken as the lowest point on the device.

National Sentence Text: An atmospheric vacuum breaker shall be installed so that the critical level is at least the distance specified by the manufacturer at which the device will operate safely but not less than 25 mm above the flood level rim of a fixture or tank, or the highest point open to atmosphere in an irrigation system.
P/T Sentence Text: An atmospheric vacuum breaker shall be installed so that the critical level is at least the distance specified by the manufacturer at which the device will operate safely but not less than 25 mm above, the flood level rim of a fixture or tank, or  the highest point open to atmosphere in an irrigation system.

National Sentence Text: A pressure vacuum breaker or spill-resistant pressure vacuum breaker shall be installed so that the critical level is not less than 300 mm above the flood level rim of a fixture or tank, or the highest point open to atmosphere in an irrigation system.
P/T Sentence Text: A pressure vacuum breaker or spill-resistant pressure vacuum breaker shall be installed with its critical level at least 300 mm above, the flood level rim of a fixture or tank, or  the highest point open to atmosphere in an irrigation system.

National Sentence Text: No bypass piping or other device capable of reducing the effectiveness of a backflow preventer shall be installed in a water supply system.
Water distribution systems shall be designed to provide peak demand flow when the flow pressures at the supply openings conform to the plumbing supply fitting manufacturer's specifications.
P/T Sentence Text: Every water distribution system shall be designed to provide peak demand flow when the flow pressures at the supply openings conform to the plumbing supply fitting manufacturer s specifications.

National Sentence Text: Potable water systems shall be designed, fabricated and installed in accordance with good engineering practice, such as that described in the ASHRAE Handbooks and ASPE Data Books. (See Note A-2.6.3.1.(2).)
P/T Sentence Text: A potable water system shall be designed, constructed and installed to conform to good engineering practice appropriate to the circumstances, such as that described in the ASHRAE Handbooks and ASPE Data Books. (See Appendix A.)

National Sentence Text: In one- and two-family dwelling units and manufactured homes, multi-purpose systems that combine potable water systems and residential fire sprinkler systems shall be designed, fabricated and installed in accordance with NFPA 13D-2016 Installation of Sprinkler Systems in One- and Two-Family Dwellings and Manufactured Homes
Water service pipes shall be sized according to the peak demand flow but shall not be less than ¾ inch size.
P/T Sentence Text: Every water service pipe shall be sized according to the peak demand flow but shall not be less than ¾ in. in size.

National Sentence Text: The temperature of water discharging into a bathtub shall not exceed 49°C.

Except as provided in Sentence 2.7.4.1.(2), non-potable water systems shall be designed, fabricated and installed in accordance with good engineering practice, such as that described in the ASHRAE Handbooks, ASPE Handbooks and CSA CAN/CSA-B128.1-06 Design and Installation of Non-Potable Water Systems
P/T Sentence Text: Non-potable water systems for re-use purposes shall be designed, constructed and installed to conform to good engineering practice appropriate to the circumstances such as described in,  the ASHRAE Handbooks,  ASPE Data Books, or  CAN/CSA-B128.1, "Design and Installation of Non-Potable Water Systems".

National Sentence Text: Non-potable water systems shall only be used to supply water closets, urinals, and directly connected underground irrigation systems that only dispense water below the surface of the ground.
This Part applies to all buildings covered in this Code. (See Article 1.1.1.1. of Division A.)

For the purpose of compliance with this Code as required in Clause 1.2.1.1.(1) of Division A, the objective and functional statements attributed to the acceptable solutions in Division B shall be the objective and functional statements identified in Sections 3.5., 4.5., 5.5., 6.5., 7.5. and 8.5. (See Note A-1.1.3.1.(1).)

The climatic values required for the design of buildings under this Code shall be in conformance with the values established by the authority having jurisdiction or, in the absence of such data, with the climatic values in Table C-1 for the location nearest to the building site. (See Note A-1.1.4.1.(1).)
The symbols and other abbreviations in Division B shall have themeanings assigned to them in Article 1.4.2.1. of Division A and Article 1.3.2.1.
Words that appear in italics are defined in Article 1.4.1.2. of Division A.
Calculations and tests performed in accordance with Sentence  shall be carried out at an average temperature of 24±2°C and under a temperature difference of 22±2°C.

National Article Title: 3.1.1.6. Calculation of Fenestration and Door Areas 1) Fenestration and door areas shall be calculated to
National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence , in the calculation of allowable fenestration and door area, the gross wall area shall be calculated as the sum of the areas of all above-ground wall assemblies including fenestration and doors, but not including parapets, projected fins, ornamentation and appendages.
Variation Label: Above-ground Components of the Building Envelope

National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence , the building envelope shall be designed to avoid increasing the overall thermal transmittance of the insulation material due to air leakage or convection, wetting, or moisture bypassing the plane of thermal resistance. (See Note A-3.2.1.1.(1).)

Where any of the conditions described in Clauses  to  occur as a result of the designed building envelope system, their effect on the overall thermal transmittance of the insulation material shall be calculated in accordance with Article 3.1.1.5.

Except as provided in Sentence , joints between components of the building envelope, such as expansion or construction joints or joints between walls and doors or fenestration, shall be insulated in a manner that provides continuity across such joints. (See Note A-3.2.1.2.(6).)
The total skylight area shall be less than 2% of the gross roof area as determined in Article 3.1.1.6.

Except as provided in Sentence , a door that separates conditioned space from the exterior shall be protected with an enclosed vestibule whose doors opening into and out of the vestibule are equipped with self-closing devices.

Except for doors equipped with power operators in barrier-free entrances, vestibules required in Sentence  shall be designed so that users passing through the vestibule are not required to open the interior and exterior doors at the same time.

A vestibule is not required for an exterior door that is a revolving door, is used primarily to facilitate vehicular movement or material handling, is intended to be used as a service, emergency exit, or stairwell exit door only, is intended to be used as a seasonal use door, such as a door leading to a patio, opens directly from a dwelling unit, opens directly from a retail space less than 200 m2 in area or from a space less than 150 m2 for other uses, or is located in a building less than 5 storeys in building height in any area that has fewer than 3500 heating degree-days (°C) as listed in Table C-1.

National Article Title: 3.2.2.2. Thermal Characteristics of Above-ground Opaque Building Assemblies
National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentences  and  and in Sentence 3.2.1.3.(1), the overall thermal transmittance of above-ground opaque building assemblies shall be not more than that shown in Table 3.2.2.2. for the building or part thereof enclosed by the opaque building assembly, for the applicable heating-degree-day category taken at 18°C. (See Note A-3.2.2.2.(1).)
P/T Article Title: 1.1.1.6. Enhancements to Division B, Part 3 Building Envelope of the 2015 NECB
P/T Sentence Text: Table 3.2.2.2. in Division B of the 2015 NECB shall be substituted with the following:
Variation Label: Above-ground Components of the Building Envelope

National Article Title: 3.2.2.2. Thermal Characteristics of Above-ground Opaque Building Assemblies
National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentences  and  and in Sentence 3.2.1.3.(1), the overall thermal transmittance of above-ground opaque building assemblies shall be not more than that shown in Table 3.2.2.2. for the building or part thereof enclosed by the opaque building assembly, for the applicable heating degree-day category taken at 18°C. (See Note A-3.2.2.2.(1).)

Except as provided in Sentences ,  and 3.2.1.3.(1), the overall thermal transmittance of fenestration, shall be not more than that shown in Table 3.2.2.3. for the applicable heating degree-day category taken at 18°C, as determined in accordance with Article 3.1.1.5.
P/T Article Title: 1.1.1.6. Enhancements to Division B, Part 3 Building Envelope of the 2015 NECB
P/T Sentence Text: Table 3.2.2.3. in Division B of the 2015 NECB shall be substituted with the following:

National Article Title: 3.2.2.4. Thermal Characteristics of Doors and Access Hatches
National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentences  and , the overall thermal transmittance of doors in semi-heated buildings, as defined in Sentence 1.2.1.2.(2), shall be not more than that shown in Table 3.2.2.4. for the applicable heating degree-day category taken at 15°C, as determined in accordance with Article 3.1.1.5.

National Article Title: 3.2.2.4. Thermal Characteristics of Doors and Access Hatches
National Sentence Text: Doors need not comply with Sentence  or  where their total area does not exceed 2% of the gross wall area calculated in accordance with Article 3.1.1.6., and their overall thermal transmittance does not exceed 4.4 W/(m2·K).
Variation Label: Above-ground Components of the Building Envelope

National Article Title: 3.2.2.4. Thermal Characteristics of Doors and Access Hatches
National Sentence Text: Storm doors, automatic sliding glass doors, revolving doors, and fire shutters need not comply with Sentence  or . (See Note A-3.2.2.4.(5).)
Variation Label: Above-ground Components of the Building Envelope

National Article Title: 3.2.3.1. Thermal Characteristics of Walls in Contact with the Ground
National Sentence Text: Where radiant heating cables or heating or cooling pipes or membranes are embedded in the surface of a wall or portion thereof that is below the exterior ground level and that separates conditioned space fromthe ground, the wall shall have an overall thermal transmittance no greater than 80% of that required by Sentence . (See Note A-3.2.2.2.(4).)

National Article Title: 3.2.3.1. Thermal Characteristics of Walls in Contact with the Ground
National Sentence Text: Where the top of the footing is less than 0.6 m below the exterior ground level, the same level of insulation stated in Sentence  shall be placed on the top or bottom surface of the floor for a distance not less than 1.2 m from the perimeter.

National Article Title: 3.2.3.2. Thermal Characteristics of Roofs in Contact with the Ground
National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence , the overall thermal transmittance of below-ground roofs that are part of the building envelope and are less than 1.2 m below the exterior ground level shall be not greater than that shown in Table 3.2.3.1. for the applicable heating-degree-day category taken at 18°C. (See Note A-3.2.3.2.(1).)

National Article Title: 3.2.3.2. Thermal Characteristics of Roofs in Contact with the Ground
National Sentence Text: The overall thermal transmittance of below-ground roofs that are less than 1.2 m below the exterior ground level and are part of the building envelope of semi-heated buildings, as defined in Sentence 1.2.1.2.(2), shall be not greater than that shown in Table 3.2.3.1. for the applicable heating-degree-day category taken at 15°C.

National Article Title: 3.2.3.3. Thermal Characteristics of Floors in Contact with the Ground
National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence , the overall thermal transmittance of floors separating conditioned space from the ground that are less than 0.6 m below grade in semi-heated buildings, as defined in Sentence 1.2.1.2.(2), shall be not greater than that shown in Table 3.2.3.1. for the applicable heating-degree-day category taken at 15°C.
All opaque building assemblies that act as environmental separators shall include an air barrier assembly conforming to Sentence  or .
For the purposes of this Article, use of the term fenestration does not include doors, which are covered in Article 3.2.4.4.

Metal and glass curtain walls that act as environmental separators shall have an air leakage rate not greater than 0.20 L/(s·m2) when a specimen prepared in accordance with Clause 6 of AAMA 501.5, Thermal Cycling of Exterior Walls, is tested in accordance with ASTM E 283, Determining Rate of Air Leakage Through Exterior Windows, Curtain Walls, and Doors Under Specified Pressure Differences Across the Specimen, at a pressure differential of 75 Pa.

Fixed windows and skylights that act as environmental separators shall have an air leakage rate not greater than 0.20 L/(s·m2) when tested in accordance with AAMA/WDMA/CSA 101/I.S.2/A440, NAFS North American Fenestration Standard/Specification for Windows, Doors, and Skylights, at a pressure differential of 75 Pa.

Except as provided in Sentences  and , doors that act as environmental separators shall have an air leakage rate not greater than 0.50 L/(s·m2) when tested in accordance with ASTM E 283, Determining Rate of Air Leakage Through Exterior Windows, Curtain Walls, and Doors Under Specified Pressure Differences Across the Specimen, at a pressure differential of 75 Pa.

Revolving doors and automatic commercial sliding doors, including their respective fixed sections, as well as overhead doors that act as environmental separators shall have an air leakage rate not greater than 5.0 L/(s·m2) when tested as a complete assembly in accordance with ASTM E 283, Determining Rate of Air Leakage Through Exterior Windows, Curtain Walls, and Doors Under Specified Pressure Differences Across the Specimen, at a pressure differential of 75 Pa.

Main entry exterior doors that act as environmental separators are permitted to have an air leakage rate not greater than 5.0 L/(s·m²) when tested as a complete assembly in accordance with ASTM E 283, Determining Rate of Air Leakage Through Exterior Windows, Curtain Walls, and Doors Under Specified Pressure Differences Across the Specimen, at a pressure differential of 75 Pa, provided that the total area of such doors does not exceed 2% of the gross wall area calculated in accordance with Article 3.1.1.6.
This Subsection does not apply to additions or to semi-heated buildings, as defined in Sentence 1.2.1.2.(2).

Where the construction techniques used result in increased performance compared to those required to be used by Articles 3.2.1.1. and 3.2.2.1. and Subsection 3.2.4., that difference in performance levels shall not be used in trade-off calculations. (See Note A-3.3.1.1.(6).)
Variation Label: Above-ground Components of the Building Envelope

National Sentence Text: Subject to the limitations stated in Article 3.4.1.2., where the building envelope does not comply with the requirements of Section 3.2. or 3.3., it shall comply with Part 8.
Power requirements for lighting units for internally illuminated exit signs shall conform to CAN/CSA-C860, Internally Lighted Exit Signs.
Fluorescent lamp ballasts shall conform to CSA C654, Fluorescent Lamp Ballast Efficacy Measurements.

National Article Title: 4.2.1.3. Limits to Installed Interior Lighting Power
National Sentence Text: Only one of the methods described in Sentence  shall be selected for use within the same building.

National Article Title: 4.2.1.4. Determination of the Installed Interior Lighting Power
National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentences  and , the installed interior lighting power shall include all power used by the luminaires, including lamps, ballasts, transformers, and control devices.

National Article Title: 4.2.1.4. Determination of the Installed Interior Lighting Power
National Sentence Text: The determination of the installed interior lighting power shall include connected lighting power for both permanently installed interior lighting and supplemental interior lighting provided by movable or plug-in luminaires, and in cases where two or more independently operating lighting systems in a space are controlled to prevent simultaneous operation, the lighting system with the highest wattage.

National Article Title: 4.2.1.5. Calculation of Interior Lighting Power Allowance Using the Building Area Method
National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence , interior lighting power allowance calculations shall be based on the primary use for which the building is intended.
Except as provided in Sentence , interior lighting controls shall be installed in accordance with this Article for each space type in the building.
P/T Article Title: 1.1.1.7. Enhancements to Division B, Part 4 Lighting of the 2015 NECB
P/T Sentence Text: Minimum lighting control requirements in Table 4.2.1.6. of the 2015 NECB shall apply

National Sentence Text: At least one manual lighting control device shall be installed in conformance with Sentence  in each space type listed in Table 4.2.1.6. to control all the lighting in each area less than or equal to 250 m2, where the area of the space is less than or equal to 1 000 m2, and in each area less than or equal to 1 000 m2, where the area of the space is greater than 1 000 m2.
Except as provided in Sentence , manual lighting control devices referred to in Sentence  shall be installed in a readily accessible location from which occupants can see the controlled lighting.

Up to 50% of the lighting power for the general lighting, and for no other lighting, in spaces requiring controls that are restricted to Partial Automatic ON in accordance with Table 4.2.1.6. is permitted to turn on automatically.

Except as provided in Sentence , the general lighting in primary and secondary sidelighted areas, as applicable, in spaces requiring Automatic Daylight Responsive Controls for Sidelighting in accordance with Table 4.2.1.6. shall be separately controlled by photocontrols that comply with Sentence , where the combined input power of all the general lighting that is completely or partially within the primary sidelighted areas is 150 W or greater, or the combined input power of all the general lighting that is completely or partially within the primary and secondary sidelighted areas is 300 W or greater.

The photocontrols required in Sentence  shall reduce electric lighting power in response to available daylight through at least one intermediate level of lighting that is equivalent to 50% to 70% of design lighting power, at least one other intermediate level of lighting that is equivalent to 20% to 40% of design lighting power, or the lowest dimming level the technology allows, as well as a control point that turns off all the controlled lighting, or continuous dimming, control the general lighting in the secondary sidelighted area independently of the general lighting in the primary sidelighted area, and be readily accessible for calibration adjustments. (See Note A-4.2.2.1. and .)

Except as provided in Sentence , the general lighting in daylighted areas under skylights and roof monitors in spaces requiring Automatic Daylight Responsive Controls for Toplighting in accordance with Table 4.2.1.6. shall be controlled by photocontrols that comply with Sentence , where the combined input power of all the general lighting that is completely or partially within the daylighted areas under skylights and under roof monitors is 150 W or greater.

The photocontrols required in Sentence  shall reduce electric lighting power in response to available daylight through at least one intermediate level of lighting that is equivalent to 50% to 70% of design lighting power, at least one other intermediate level of lighting that is equivalent to 20% to 40% of design lighting power, or the lowest dimming level the technology allows, as well as a control point that turns off all the controlled lighting, or continuous dimming, control the general lighting in overlapping toplighted and sidelighted areas together with the general lighting in the daylighted areas under skylights or roof monitors, and be readily accessible for calibration adjustments. (See Note A-4.2.2.1. and .)

General lighting in the following areas need not comply with Sentence : daylighted areas under skylights and roof monitors where it can be demonstrated that existing adjacent structures or natural objects block direct sunlight for more than 1 500 hours per year between 8 a.m. and 4 p.m., daylighted areas where the visual transmittance, VT, of the skylights and roof monitors is less than 0.4, and spaces in buildings located above the 55°N latitude where the input power of the general lighting within daylighted areas is less than 200 W.

Except as provided in Sentence , the power for general lighting in spaces requiring controls that are Automatic Partial OFF in accordance with Table 4.2.1.6. shall automatically reduce by 50% or more within 20 min of the space being unoccupied.

Except as provided in Sentence , the lighting in spaces requiring controls that are Automatic Full OFF in accordance with Table 4.2.1.6. shall be controlled by automatic control devices that shut off the lighting within 20 min of the space being unoccupied, where each automatic control device controls an area not greater than 50 m2.

The following lighting applications need not comply with Sentence : general lighting and task lighting in shop and laboratory classrooms, general lighting and task lighting in spaces where automatic shut-off would endanger the safety or security of the building occupants, and lighting required to operate continuously due to operational requirements.

Except as provided in Sentence , the lighting in spaces requiring controls that are Scheduled Shut-off in accordance with Table 4.2.1.6. shall shut off automatically during periods when the spaces are scheduled to be unoccupied by means of control devices complying with Sentence  that are time-of-day operated control devices that automatically turn the lighting off at programmed times, or signals from other automatic control devices or alarm/security systems.
A control device installed to meet the requirements of Sentence  shall control the lighting for an area of not more than 2 500 m2 on not more than one floor.

Any manual control device installed to override the Scheduled Shut-off control device required in Sentence  shall turn the lighting on for 2 h or less per activation during scheduled off periods, and control an area of 500 m2 or less.

Lighting need not be controlled in accordance with Sentence  where it is required to operate continuously due to operational requirements, located in spaces where patient care is rendered, or located in spaces where automatic shut-off would endanger the safety or security of the building occupants.

Except as provided in Sentence , the lighting power in a lighting zone referred to in Sentence  shall be controlled by a device that automatically reduces the lighting power by at least 30% when no activity is detected for 20 min.

Except as provided in Sentence , where the combined input of all luminaires within 6.1 m of any perimeter wall having a net opening-to-wall ratio of at least 40% and no exterior obstructions within 6.1 m exceeds 150 W, the power to those luminaires shall be automatically reduced in response to daylight.

National Article Title: 4.2.2.3. Determination of Primary and Secondary Sidelighted Areas
National Sentence Text: The width of the primary sidelighted area shall be calculated as the width of the window plus, on each side, the smaller of the following values: ½ of the window head height, or the distance to any vertical obstruction that is 1.5mor more in height.
